Foundational Essays

Foundational essays documenting the core arguments, evidence chains, and legal analysis for Thomson v NHS Providers

BREACH
CRITICAL v2.0 (Corrected)

Somatoform Contamination: The Covert Diagnosis

How a Psychiatric Label Was Applied Without Assessment, Knowledge, or Basis

Documents how Dr Bulale Ali applied Somatoform Pain Disorder (F45.4) during a telephone consultation about opioid medication switching on 5 January 2023 - after MRI had confirmed T5-T8 vertebral fractures. The patient was never informed. The diagnosis was later removed by Dr Gorrie in July 2025 with the note 'there were clear causes for his pain.'

Key Arguments

  • Psychiatric diagnosis applied without psychiatric assessment
  • Applied after objective pathology (vertebral fractures) confirmed on imaging
  • Patient never informed of diagnosis
  • Wrong ICD-10 code used (E278 instead of F45.4) suggesting unfamiliarity
  • +2 more arguments

Related Findings

BREACH
CRITICAL v1.0

The 10-Month Diagnostic Delay

How T5-T8 Vertebral Fractures Went Undiagnosed Despite Red Flag Presentation

Documents the 10-month delay in diagnosing T5-T8 vertebral fractures from the December 2021 seizure until MRI confirmation in October 2022. Initial A&E assessment dismissed the injury as 'soft tissue' despite NICE NG59 red flag presentation. The delay was compounded by imaging the wrong spinal region (lumbar instead of thoracic).

Key Arguments

  • NICE NG59 red flags present but not actioned
  • Initial A&E dismissed injury as 'soft tissue'
  • Wrong spinal region imaged (lumbar MRI when thoracic was symptomatic)
  • Patient discharged from Neurospine because 'no surgical target' - on lumbar MRI
  • +2 more arguments

Related Findings

CAUSATION
CRITICAL v1.0

Medication Causation: Pregabalin Withdrawal and Seizure

How Abrupt Pregabalin Reduction Led to the Index Seizure Event

Documents the causation chain linking abrupt pregabalin reduction (600mg to 100mg) in October 2021 to the seizure event on 23 December 2021. BNF guidance mandates gradual withdrawal over minimum 1 week. Dr Simeoni documented: 'When had a seizure pregabalin had been stopped abruptly.' The patient now has a formal epilepsy diagnosis.

Key Arguments

  • BNF mandates gradual pregabalin withdrawal - not followed
  • Reduction from 600mg to 100mg in 2-3 days
  • Independent specialist documented seizure occurred when pregabalin stopped abruptly
  • Sleep deprivation (14+ months) lowered seizure threshold
  • +2 more arguments

Related Findings

VINDICATION
CRITICAL v1.0

The Vindication Evidence

Independent Specialist Confirmations That Refute Psychiatric Framing

Compiles the independent specialist statements that vindicate John Thomson's physical symptoms and refute the psychiatric/functional framing. Dr Karunaratne: 'medical explanations have been found.' Dr Gorrie removed somatoform noting 'clear causes for his pain.' Pain Clinic stated somatoform was 'NOT their opinion.' Multiple imaging studies confirm TOS over 6 years.

Key Arguments

  • Dr Gorrie independently removed somatoform diagnosis
  • Pain Clinic explicitly disagreed with somatoform characterisation
  • Dr Karunaratne: 'medical explanations have been found for symptoms'
  • Formal epilepsy diagnosis (not NEAD/functional seizures)
  • +3 more arguments

Related Findings

PROCEDURAL
v1.0

Practice Manager Conduct

Non-Clinical Decisions With Clinical Consequences

Documents the conduct of practice manager Clive Polles in making clinical decisions without clinical authority. iMessage evidence shows direct involvement in medication decisions. Dr Gorrie referenced 'sketchy stuff' that blocked a practice merger. Medication refused 4 days before the December 2021 seizure.

Key Arguments

  • Practice manager made clinical decisions without clinical qualifications
  • Medication refused 4 days before index seizure event
  • Direct text messages from Polles to patient/family about clinical matters
  • Current GP referenced 'sketchy stuff' blocking practice merger
  • +2 more arguments

BREACH
CRITICAL v1.0

Thoracic Outlet Syndrome: The Ongoing Delay

Six Years of Documented Vascular Pathology

Documents the 6+ year timeline of Thoracic Outlet Syndrome from first positive Doppler in June 2019 through subsequent confirmatory imaging in 2024 and 2025. Despite objective evidence of vascular compression, the condition has not received definitive surgical intervention. Patient symptom severity documented: 'would rather his arm be amputated.'

Key Arguments

  • First positive Doppler June 2019 - 'marked haemodynamic changes'
  • 2024 MR confirms dynamic subclavian compression
  • 2025 Doppler: bilateral subclavian veins 'compressed with no flow'
  • Radiologist: 'TOS cannot be excluded' with static imaging
  • +3 more arguments
